<|endoftext|>/*
Check if in given vector of numbers, are any two numbers closer to each other than
given threshold.
>>> has_close_elements({1.0, 2.0, 3.0}, 0.5)
false
>>> has_close_elements({1.0, 2.8, 3.0, 4.0, 5.0, 2.0}, 0.3)
true
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <math.h>
using std;
bool has_close_elements(vector < float > numbers, float threshold) {
    int i, j;
   
    for (i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        for (j = i + 1; j < numbers.size(); j++) {
            if (fabs(numbers[i] - numbers[j]) < threshold) {
                return true;
            }
        }
    }
    return false;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a positive integer n, you have to make a pile of n levels of stones.
The first level has n stones.
The number of stones in the next level is:
    - the next odd number if n is odd.
    - the next even number if n is even.
Return the number of stones in each level in a vector, where element at index
i represents the number of stones in the level (i+1).

Examples:
>>> make_a_pile(3)
{3, 5, 7}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > make_a_pile(int n) {
   
    vector < int > pile;
    pile.reserve(n);
    
    for(int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        if((i%2) == 0) {
            pile.push_back(i);
        }
        else {
            pile.push_back(i+1);
        }
    }
    return pile;
}

>>> make_a_pile(3)
{3, 5, 7}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > make_a_pile(int n) {
   
    vector < int > pile;
    pile.reserve(n);
    
    for(int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        if((i%2) == 0) {
            pile.push_back(i);
        }
        else {
            pile.push_back(i+1);
        }
    }
    return pile;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Out of vector of strings, return the longest one. Return the first one in case of multiple
strings of the same length. Return None in case the input vector is empty.
>>> longest({})

>>> longest({"a", "b", "c"})
"a"
>>> longest({"a", "bb", "ccc"})
"ccc"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
string longest(vector < string > strings) {
    string out;
   
    if (strings.empty()) {
        return out;
    }
    
    size_t longest = 0;
    for (size_t i = 0; i < strings.size(); i++) {
        if (strings[i].size() > longest) {
            longest = strings[i].size();
        }
    }
    
    for (size_t i = 0; i < strings.size(); i++) {
        if (strings[i].size() == longest) {
            out = strings[i];
        }
    }
    
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Evaluate whether the given number n can be written as the sum of exactly 4 positive even numbers
Example
is_equal_to_sum_even(4) == false
is_equal_to_sum_even(6) == false
is_equal_to_sum_even(8) == true
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
bool is_equal_to_sum_even(int n) {
   
    int sum = 0;
    for(int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        sum += i;
    }
    
    return sum % 4 == 0;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
The Brazilian factorial is defined as:
brazilian_factorial(n) = n! * (n-1)! * (n-2)! *... * 1!
where n > 0

For example:
>>> special_factorial(4)
288

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
factorial of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long special_factorial(int n){
    long long fact=1,bfact=1;
    for (int i=1;i<=n;i++)
        fact*=i;
    for (int i=1;i<=n;i++)
        bfact*=i;
    return fact*bfact;
}
/*
The function will receive an integer as input and should return the factorial

Write a function which sorts the given vector of integers
in ascending order according to the sum of their digits.
Note: if there are several items with similar sum of their digits,
order them based on their index in original vector.

For example:
>>> order_by_points({1, 11, -1, -11, -12}) == {-1, -11, 1, -12, 11}
>>> order_by_points({}) == {}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < int > order_by_points(vector < int > nums) {
    vector < int > sumdigit = {
        }
    ;
    for (int i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++)
     {
        string w = to_string(abs(nums [ i ]));
        int sum = 0;
        for (int j = 1; j < w.length(); j++)
        sum+=w [ j ] - 48;
        if (nums [ i ] > 0) sum+=w [ 0 ] - 48;
       
        sumdigit [ i ] = sum;
    }
    vector < int > result;
    for (int i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++)
    {
        vector < int > tmp;
        for (int j = 0; j < sumdigit.size(); j++)
        {
            if (sumdigit[j] == sumdigit[i])
            {
                tmp [ j ] = nums [ i ];
            }
        }
        result [ i ] = tmp [ 0 ];
    }
    return result;
}

Write a function that accepts a vector of strings as a parameter,
deletes the strings that have odd lengths from it,
and returns the resulted vector with a sorted order,
The vector is always a vector of strings and never a vector of numbers,
and it may contain duplicates.
The order of the vector should be ascending by length of each word, and you
should return the vector sorted by that rule.
If two words have the same length, sort the vector alphabetically.
The function should return a vector of strings in sorted order.
You may assume that all words will have the same length.

    vector < string > out = {
        }

while (i < lst.size()) {
        if (lst [ i ].length() % 2 == 0) out.push_back(lst [ i ]);

}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given an integer. return a vector that has the number of even and odd digits respectively.

 Example:
    even_odd_count(-12) ==> {1, 1}
    even_odd_count(123) ==> {1, 2}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <string>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > even_odd_count(int num) {
   
    vector < int > even;
    vector < int > odd;
    int count = 0;
    
    while(num > 0) {
        
        if(num % 2 == 0) {
            even.push_back(count);
            count++;
        }
        
        else {
            odd.push_back(count);
            count++;
        }
        
        num = num / 2;
    }
    
    return even;
}

#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <string>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > even_odd_count(int num) {
   
    vector < int > even;
    vector < int > odd;
    int count = 0;
    
    while(num > 0) {
        
        if(num % 2 == 0) {
            even.push_back(count);
            count++;
        }
        
        else {
            odd.push_back(count);
            count++;
        }
        
        num = num / 2;
    }
    
    return even;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Find how many times a given substring can be found in the original string. Count overlaping cases.
>>> how_many_times("", "a")
0
>>> how_many_times("aaa", "a")
3
>>> how_many_times("aaaa", "aa")
3
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
int how_many_times(string str, string substring) {
    int out = 0;
   
    for (int i = 0; i < str.size(); i++) {
        if (str[i] == substring[0]) {
            for (int j = 1; j < substring.size(); j++) {
                if (str[i + j]!= substring[j]) {
                    break;
                }
            }
            if (j == substring.size()) {
                out ++;
            }
        }
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Filter given vector of any python values only for integers
>>> filter_integers({"a", 3.14, 5})
{5}
>>> filter_integers({1, 2, 3, "abc", {}, {}})
{1, 2, 3}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
#include <boost/any.hpp>
#include <list>
typedef std :: list < boost :: any > list_any;
using std;
vector < int > filter_integers(list_any values) {
    list_any :: iterator it;
   
    vector < int > result;
    
    for (it = values.begin(); it!= values.end(); ++it) {
        boost :: any & value = *it;
        
        if (value.type() == typeid(int)) {
            result.push_back(value.cast<int>());
        }
    }
    
    return result;
}

/*
Filter given vector of any python values only for tuples
>>> filter_tuples({"a", 3.14, 5})
{5}
>>> filter_tuples({1, 2, 3, "abc", {}, {}})
{1, 2, 3}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
#include <boost/any.hpp>
#include <list>
typedef std :: list < boost :: any > list_any;
using std;
vector < tuple < string, string > > filter_tuples(list_any values) {
    list_any :: iterator it;
   
    vector < tuple < string, string > > result;
    
    for (it = values.begin(); it!= values.end(); ++it) {
        boost :: any & value = *it;
        
        if (value.type() == typeid(tuple)) {
            vector < string > strings;
            
            for (it = value.begin(); it!= value.end(); ++it) {
                boost :: any & v = *it;
                
                if (v.type() == typeid(string)) {
                    strings.push_back(v.cast<string>());
                }
            }
            
            result.push_back(tuple(strings));
        }
    }
    
    return result;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that start with a given prefix.
>>> filter_by_prefix({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_prefix({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_prefix(vector < string > strings, string prefix) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.substr(0, prefix.size()) == prefix) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_suffix(vector < string > strings, string suffix) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.substr(s.size() - suffix.size(), suffix.size()) == suffix) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

{}

{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_substring(vector < string > strings, string substring) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.find(substring)!= string::npos) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return only positive numbers in the vector.
>>> get_positive({-1, 2, -4, 5, 6})
{2, 5, 6}
>>> get_positive({5, 3, -5, 2, -3, 3, 9, 0, 123, 1, -10})
{5, 3, 2, 3, 9, 123, 1}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < float > get_positive(vector < float > l) {
   
   vector < float > positive;
   
   for (int i = 0; i < l.size(); i++) {
      if (l[i] > 0) {
         positive.push_back(l[i]);
      }
   }
   return positive;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return true if a given number is prime, and false otherwise.
>>> is_prime(6)
false
>>> is_prime(101)
true
>>> is_prime(11)
true
>>> is_prime(13441)
true
>>> is_prime(61)
true
>>> is_prime(4)
false
>>> is_prime(1)
false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
bool is_prime(long long n) {
    if (n < 2) return false;
   
    long long i = 2;
    while (i <= sqrt(n)) {
        if (n % i == 0) return false;
        i++;
    }
    return true;
}

bool is_divisible(long long n, long long m) {
    if (n < m) return false;
   
    long long i = 2;
    while (i <= sqrt(n)) {
        if (n % i == 0) return false;
        i++;
    }
    return true;
}

false

false
*/

using std;

    if (n < m) return false;
   
    long long i = 2;
    while (i <= sqrt(n)) {
        if (n % i == 0) return false;
        i++;
    }
    return true;
}

double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return the number of times the digit 7 appears in integers less than n which are divisible by 11 or 13.
>>> fizz_buzz(50)
0
>>> fizz_buzz(78)
2
>>> fizz_buzz(79)
3
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int fizz_buzz(int n) {
    int count = 0;
    int i = 0;
while (i < n) {
        if (i % 11 == 0 or i % 13 == 0)
         {
            int q = i;
           
            while (q > 0) {
                q = q / 10;
                count++;
            }
        }
        i++;
    }
    return count;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
For a given vector of input numbers, calculate Mean Absolute Deviation
around the mean of this dataset.
Mean Absolute Deviation is the average absolute difference between each
element and a centerpoint (mean in this case):
MAD = average | x - x_mean |
>>> mean_absolute_deviation({1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0})
1.0
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
float mean_absolute_deviation(vector < float > numbers) {
    float sum = 0;
    float avg, msum, mavg;
    int i = 0;
   
    avg = numbers[0];
    msum = avg;
    mavg = avg;
    
    for(i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        sum += numbers[i];
        msum = msum + numbers[i];
        mavg = mavg + numbers[i];
    }
    
    avg = sum / numbers.size();
    msum = msum / numbers.size();
    mavg = mavg / numbers.size();
    
    float mdev = sqrtf((msum - avg) * (msum - avg));
    float madev = sqrtf((mavg - avg) * (mavg - avg));
    
    return (mdev > madev)? mdev : madev;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
remove_vowels is a function that takes string and returns string without vowels.
>>> remove_vowels("")
""
>>> remove_vowels("abcdef\nghijklm")
"bcdf\nghjklm"
>>> remove_vowels("abcdef")
"bcdf"
>>> remove_vowels("aaaaa")
""
>>> remove_vowels("aaBAA")
"B"
>>> remove_vowels("zbcd")
"zbcd"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
#include <algorithm>
using std;
string remove_vowels(string text) {
    string out = "";
   
    for (auto c : text) {
        if (c == 'a' || c == 'e' || c == 'i' || c == 'o' || c == 'u') {
            out += c;
        }
    }
    return out;
}

/*
is_palindrome is a function that takes string and returns true if string is a palindrome and false otherwise.
>>> is_palindrome("")
True
>>> is_palindrome("abc")
True
>>> is_palindrome("aba")
False
>>> is_palindrome("abca")
True
>>> is_palindrome("abca")
True
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
#include <algorithm>
using std;
bool is_palindrome(string text) {
    string out = "";
   
    for (auto c : text) {
        if (c == 'a' || c == 'e' || c == 'i' || c == 'o' || c == 'u') {
            out += c;
        }
    }
    return out == reverse(out);
}

    for (auto c : text) {
        if (c == 'a' || c == 'e' || c == 'i' || c == 'o' || c == 'u') {
            out += c;
        }

<|endoftext|>/*
Return true is vector elements are monotonically increasing or decreasing.
>>> monotonic({1, 2, 4, 20})
true
>>> monotonic({1, 20, 4, 10})
false
>>> monotonic({4, 1, 0, -10})
true
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
bool monotonic(vector < float > l) {
    int incr, decr;
    incr = 0; decr = 0;
    int i = 1;
while (i < l.size()) {
       
        if (l[i] > l[i-1]) {
            incr++;
        } else {
            decr++;
        }
        i++;
    }
    if (incr > decr) {
        return true;
    } else {
        return false;
    }
}

<|endoftext|>/*
brackets is a string of '(' and ')'.
return true if every opening bracket has a corresponding closing bracket.

>>> correct_bracketing("(")
false
>>> correct_bracketing("()")
true
>>> correct_bracketing("(()())")
true
>>> correct_bracketing(")(()")
false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
bool correct_bracketing(string brackets) {
    int level = 0;
    int i = 0;
while (i < brackets.length()) {
         {
           
           if (brackets[i] == '(') {
               level++;
           }
           else if (brackets[i] == ')') {
               level--;
           }
           i++;
           if (level < 0) {
               return false;
           }
         }
    }
    return true;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Circular shift the digits of the integer x, shift the digits right by shift
and return the result as a string.
If shift > number of digits, return digits reversed.
>>> circular_shift(12, 1)
"21"
>>> circular_shift(12, 2)
"12"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
string circular_shift(int x, int shift) {
    string xs;
    xs = to_string(x);
    if (xs.length() < shift)
   
        return xs;
    
    int n = xs.length();
    int m = xs.length() - shift;
    
    for (int i = n; i >= m; i--)
        xs.insert(i, xs.at(i + shift));
    
    return xs;
}

/*
Return the sum of the digits of x.
>>> sum_digits(123)
6
>>> sum_digits(-123)
6
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
int sum_digits(int x) {
    int sum = 0;
    while (x > 0) {
        sum += x % 10;
        x /= 10;
    }
    return sum;
}

/*
Return the product of the digits of x.
>>> product_digits(123)
6
>>> product_digits(-123)
6
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
int product_digits(int x) {
    int product = 1;
    while (x > 0) {
        product *= x % 10;
        x /= 10;
    }
    return product;
}

/*
Return the greatest common divisor of x and y.
>>> gcd_digits(123, 456)
3
>>> gcd_digits(123, 456)
3
>>> gcd_digits(123, 456)
3
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
int gcd_digits(int x, int y) {
    int gcd = 0;
    while (x!= 0) {
        while (y!= 0) {
            if (x % y == 0)
                gcd = y;
            y /= 10;
        }
        x /= 10;
    }
    return gcd;
}

/*
Return the least common multiple of x and y.
>>> lcm(123, 456)
123
>>> lcm(123, 456)
123
>>> lcm(123, 456)
123
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
int lcm(int x, int y) {
    return (x * y) / gcd_digits(x, y);
}

<|endoftext|>/*
For a given vector of integers, return a vector consisting of a sum and a product of all the integers in a vector.
Empty sum should be equal to 0 and empty product should be equal to 1.
>>> sum_product({})
(0, 1)
>>> sum_product({1, 2, 3, 4})
(10, 24)
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > sum_product(vector < int > numbers) {
    int sum = 0, product = 1;
    int i = 0;
while (i < numbers.size()) {
       
        sum += numbers[i];
        product *= numbers[i];
        i++;
    }
    vector < int > result;
    result.push_back(sum);
    result.push_back(product);
    return result;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Write a function that takes a string and returns true if the string
length is a prime number or false otherwise
Examples
prime_length("Hello") == true
prime_length("abcdcba") == true
prime_length("kittens") == true
prime_length("orange") == false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
bool prime_length(string str) {
    int l, i;
   
    l = str.length();
    for(i = 2; i <= l; i++) {
        if(str[i] == str[0]) {
            int j;
            for(j = i; j < l; j++) {
                if(str[j]!= str[i]) {
                    break;
                }
            }
            if(j == l) {
                return true;
            }
        }
    }
    return false;
}

/*
Write a function that takes a string and returns true if the string
contains only letters or false otherwise
Examples
letter_only("Hello") == true
letter_only("abcdcba") == false
letter_only("kittens") == false
letter_only("orange") == false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
bool letter_only(string str) {
    int l, i;
   
    l = str.length();
    for(i = 0; i <= l; i++) {
        if(str[i] < 'a' || str[i] > 'z') {
            return false;
        }
    }
    return true;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function encrypt that takes a string as an argument and
returns a string encrypted with the alphabet being rotated. 
The alphabet should be rotated in a manner such that the letters 
shift down by two multiplied to two places.
For example:
encrypt("hi") returns "lm"
encrypt("asdfghjkl") returns "ewhjklnop"
encrypt("gf") returns "kj"
encrypt("et") returns "ix"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
string encrypt(string s) {
    string out;
    int i;
   
    for (i = 0; i<s.length(); i++) {
        out[i] = s[s.length()-1-i];
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
From a given vector of integers, generate a vector of rolling maximum element found until given moment
in the sequence.
>>> rolling_max({1, 2, 3, 2, 3, 4, 2})
{1, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 4}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > rolling_max(vector < int > numbers) {
    vector < int > out;
    int max = 0;
   
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        if(numbers[i] > max) {
            max = numbers[i];
        }
    }
    out.push_back(max);
    
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        if(numbers[i] >= max) {
            out.push_back(numbers[i]);
        }
    }
    
    return out;
}

*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > rolling_min(vector < int > numbers) {
    vector < int > out;
    int min = 0;
   
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        if(numbers[i] < min) {
            min = numbers[i];
        }
    }
    out.push_back(min);
    
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        if(numbers[i] <= min) {
            out.push_back(numbers[i]);
        }
    }
    
    return out;
}
